DOC.HEAD: U.S. Condemns Romanian Repression
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States on Tuesday condemned the violent suppression of political dissent in Romania, saying the Bush administration is reviewing its already limited relationship with the hard-line East Bloc country. ``We call upon the Romanian government to cease these outrageous policies and allow its citizens freely to exercise their fundamental human rights,'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said, reading an official statement denouncing ``the brutal use of security forces against the people of Timisoara.'' The extent of the weekend violence in Timisoara, a city 500 miles west of Bucharest, was difficult to determine because the government was apparently suppressing news of the events, she said. Two U.S. Embassy officials have been sent from Bucharest to try to get first-hand information, she said. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater also harshly criticized the Romanian government. ``The demonstrations in Timisoara and elsewhere were a result of the systematic denial of human rights to the people of Romania, particularly to members of the Hungarian minority,'' Fitzwater said Tuesday. ``The repressive measures undertaken by the Romanian government are totally unjustified and stand in stark contrast to the positive changes taking place elsewhere in Eastern Europe,'' he said. Ms. Tutwiler said U.S. Ambassador Alan Green will await the report from the Embassy officials and the return of leader Nicolae Ceaucescu from an official trip to Iran before deciding whether to file an official diplomatic protest. ``The demonstrations were an obvious manifestation of broad popular discontent with the policies of the Romanian government and a clear expression of the Romanian people's desire to join their neighbors in embracing democratic reform and economic freedom,'' the State Department statement said. ``It is sadly regrettable that Romania remains the only Warsaw Pact country to reject all political and economic reforms,'' as well as the only signatory to the Helsinki human rights accord to refuse to acknowledge the commitments it made under that agreement, Ms. Tutwiler said. She said international borders and the Bucharest airport have been closed to foreign visitors and all international telephone lines into Romania were getting busy signals. The few U.S. citizens in Timisoara known to the Embassy are safe, she said. The United States, Ms. Tutwiler said, is coordinating its response to the Romanian crackdown with NATO and European Economic Community allies. ``I can tell you we are currently reassessing our bilateral relationship, including economic, scientific and other areas to determine if there are other actions which can be meaningfully taken,'' she said. U.S. trade with Romania has declined by half since 1988 when it renounced most-favored-nation status to get out from under U.S. freedom-of-emigration requirements the status imposes. The only trade remaining is about $300 million annually, primarily imports of Romanian refined petroleum products. ``Our relations have deteriorated seriously since then,'' Ms. Tutwiler said.
